comments.commentBody:
PETA did not create the vast overpopulation of pets in this country. Blame that on the irresponsible breeders. PETA has excellent programs to reduce the over-population problem.

Every year in the USA, there are millions more pets than there are homes for. Until the irresponsible breeders are stopped, the only choice is a brutal death or a merciful one. Thank goodness some are providing merciful ones.

I enjoyed watching horse races but after looking at the PETA video I'll never watch another horse race. The whole thing is rotten. None other than Gary Stevens and Wayne Lukas joking about the prevalence of electric shockers. Shame on them.

I do welcome stories such as these and this one is very well written ......But  I do take exception with your slight of Dr . Hunt . This is not the first time that the Times has chosen to attack him . I will tell you from first hand knowledge that he is fine man and does care about the horses he treats . I moved on from the Horse racing game long ago but believe me  Dr Hunt is not part of the problem . IMHO of course ......Oh , in case your wondering I have no ties to him and i'm sure he has no idea who I am . But I do support him and PETA in their investigation of Horse racing . Thank you .

Dear Dan,

I wonder how many articles the Times has run on the plight of people in Syria and how many it has run on animal cruelty. Would it perhaps be in a ratio of 3000 to one?

So just because these are suffering animals they don't deserve compassion and respect? The Times should only write about human misery? Is that your point? Or are you so outraged that the Times would write about animal suffering because you think you and your tribe are the only things that matter on this earth? Just wondering, Dan.

I would guess that people who don't give a hoot about the suffering of animals also don't care all that much about the suffering of humans. After all, humans are just another animal species.

I don't understand this (inevitable) comment. Why do we need to parcel out our sympathy in such a way? People are suffering everywhere and likely will be for a long time (and, the New York Times could hardly be accused of not covering the war in Syria!) Do we wait? This is an important news story because horseracing is big business. It also exposes an underbelly of human nature that is difficult to reconcile with our affinity for animals. The workers in this story made $5.95 an hour. Focus on that if you would like, but there is absolutely nothing wrong with reporting on an industry that makes millions of dollars a year exploiting both animals and people for entertainment. This is not a competition.
Decent people have a duty to help protect the innocent defenseless from abuse. PETA is essential.
So Steve Asmussen isn't a highly respected trainer? You must be joking, or have no idea about the thoroughbred racing world.

This IS going on at "highly respected barns"!! The barns that are profiled are among the most lauded, awarded, trophied & victorious operations in the business. Legendary, esteemed by peers.

And it's not "shady doings". It's animal cruelty, it's the intentional infliction of pain & misery.

Exactly Robin, this is what it is, a headline-grabbing attempt by people who want to advance their own agendas in my view with no regard to whom they hurt.  There are many more who do things right that are brought down by those who do things wrong.

This is PETA and the NY Times doing its pre Derby work. Don't believe the hype. I will be shocked if my comment even gets printed.
I don't doubt shady doings in this barn but I have lots of experiences in very good racing barns where none of this would ever go on. Not every trainer is crooked and the ignorant reactions I read are just that. Unless you have experience in thoroughbreds or high end thoroughbred racing I suggest you spend some time in a highly respected barn before you comment.

"every kindergartener knows that flies don't solve calculus problems"

Kindergartners probably don't read the "Annual Review of Neuroscience". A 1989 paper on "Integrating with Neurons" "offers a model of how integration might be done by neurons, and speculates about the extent to which neural integrators occur elsewhere in motor control."[1] The word "integration" is being used as it is used in calculus.

See other references in the paper linked from the article.[2]

[1] Integrating with Neurons
Annual Review of Neuroscience
Vol. 12: 33-45 (Volume publication date March 1989)
D A Robinson
http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.ne.12.030189.000341

[2] Discovering the flight autostabilizer of fruit flies by inducing aerial stumbles
Ristroph, et al.
January 22, 2010
http://www.pnas.org/content/107/11/4820.full

Well, then: Calculus or differential equations...perhaps non-orthogonal three-dimension space so that we can usher in some tensor calculations. Who knows? in the pauses between thinking on the next banana, little guy (gal) might consider a proof of the Riemann Hypothesis.

Nice article. Take the math analogy for what it is/ is not worth and let the fly fly. Free.

Naf Saratoga CA
I hate headlines like that.  The flies aren't doing calculus.  Acorns aren't doing calculus either, even though calculus would need to be used, if engineers had to build an oak.

I love the structure of this comment.  It starts out with what looks like the beginning of a substantive critique, then immediately zigzags to a joke, then comes back to a resolved, confident conclusion--as if to imply that we've been treated to a persuasive argument in between, rather than a petty and childish diversion.

Yes the novelty of malls wears off due to consumers realizing they are too expensive to shop in. And that traces back to the inevitable property owners demnding too much in rent and upkeep. A very common old problem. Real property owners demanding expecting too much is also the inevitable reason for most inflation. And our economy is based in too large part on the bet that
propertys values will produce greatly. If anything need be regulated it is property values and the ability of the power behind it that bilks society out of its lifeblood.

@john carter - The underlying hypothesis is that gravitational waves exist. They do not. Despite extensive efforts over 50 years, no gravitational waves have ever been detected.

The polarization of light is a widely observed phenomenon and the common cause is not gravitational waves. It strains the bounds of credulity therefore that a commonly observed polarization is in this case attributed to a speculative field event that cannot be detected, based on a theory (inflation) that itself has no basis in empirical reality. This is a mathematical fairy tale and a scientific disgrace.

"...If you believe..."

Indeed it appears, in the end, your posit is premised on faith.

"...John 1.1 states, 'in the beginning was the word.'..."

Have you considered, that the above quote is intended to be a warning for the reader?

If you look at all the statistics on sudden acceleration the most complaints are from people over 70 years old, the numbers drop from here, the younger the less complaints. Ford is on the top of the list on complaints on sudden acceleration, Toyota was shacken down to pay a fine. Sudden acceleration is a driver error in most cases, look at the numbers.

Gary, you say its hard to solv a problem you can't find. Right. That's why they need far more highly advanced black boxes. They need to record more time, much more than 30 seconds, and they need to capture far more key parameters-a wider data record. Auto EDRs were only designed to support airbag deployment issues, and they don't even do that very well.

The NHTSA needs to develop and enforce far greater effective standards for auto EDRs. Yes cars are built and sold all over the world. Who will launch improved black box data collection?

Elon Musk?

Steve Asmussen doesn't have enough $ maybe jimbo you could loan him a few bucks and perhaps spend some downtime in jail talking about horse fixing and drugging...that might make an interesting news story...
Its worse with horses. The cyclists voluntarily take the PEDs. A horse is an innocent victim and wouldn't even hurt a flea, which is why the comments are flying fast and furious on this story.
If trainers and coaches in cycling are willing to subject human beings to a regimen of illegal PEDs, what do you suppose owners and trainers are willing to do to animals?

And we're still in a poor economy? Clearly not!

BTW, my dogs' daybed is where I am sitting or on the sofa or another chair. When I had large dogs, I found the beds at Orvis and LLBean served perfectly.

Strollers? Okay - for an elderly dog who still loves an outing, but for a younger, healthier dog, a walk will keep down obesity, which has become epidemic in pets these days.

Ridiculous...

linda m, Your last sentence "now I got a headache" were also my better half's exact words to describe Senor Barocas's THURXWDP mind-bender!

"GET out of TOWNs, NOW! Victor"

Howie TBOQ

I totally agree. I love my border collie, but the most I do is occasionally tie a bandanna around her neck (cost: roughly 50 cents at the thrift store). She would not tolerate nor enjoy fancy clothes or silly videos. Her idea of a really good toy is a stick out in the yard.

Let dogs be dogs, for gods sake. They are NOT very hairy children.

No, I disagree, Concerned Citizen. They *are* hairy children. Most dogs of my acquaintance have been pretty much 4 y/o little boys in fur coats. But we ought to treat our children, human or canine or feline, according to their needs. NO ONE needs a frilly outfit* or silly videos. Little children, furry and otherwise, need to go outside to play, need loads of love, and total acceptance as they are and for who they are.
(*Okay, I admit it. I made a fleece coat for my 15 y/o foxhound to wear when it's cold. She's getting skinnier & skinner and it helps keep her comfortable.)
The kid doesn't need to be "dressed up like a little princess" either. It's pathological wish-fulfillment on the part of owner *or* parent, and bad news for both dogs and children

I love dogs, especially mine, but she is a DOG, NOT A CHILD.  The thought of dressing her up like a little princess or leaving a video at home for her to watch while I'm away for two hours to reduce her anxiety is so wrong!  This kind of thinking creates more anxiety not less!  Why can't people see this?  I guess because they themselves have so much anxiety that they pass it on to their animals, especially dogs.  I feel sorry for all the dogs out there that have to live with neurotic owners who can't be satisfied with just loving their dogs for who they really are, just dogs.
Thank you for the heartwarming comment and for rescuing the three dobies.

My three red male rescue dobermans are indeed the KINGS in this family.  Coming with an assortment of injuries from past abuse--buckshot in the lungs, cigarette burns on the top of the head, embedded choke chains around the neck, broken teeth.....they now have separate beds/blankets, Greek yogurt for breakfast,  rawhide treats on demand, daily runs, weekly baths, and more.  In return, we receive unfailing love, loyalty, and daily joy.   How they "forget" and "forgive" their horrible past lives is beyond my understanding.  What a lesson in life they provide.

I can answer that.  First, because it amuses the owners.  Second, because the owners hope it gives their pets some joy.  Third, if you ever owned an Australian Cattle Dog you would understand that some dogs can never have too much mental and physical stimulation.

My mom has a miniature Dachshund she got after my dad passed away. Mr.Henry doesn't have a lot of fancy toys or devices to track his movements or activities.  He is very good about not getting on furniture except for a red recliner that he has claimed as his throne.  Mom, who is handicapped, keeps him fully involved in all her activities around her home. His favorite toys are the vacuum cleaner and the dust mop!  I have often wondered why pet owners spend big bucks on pet amusements when a lot of love and some attention seems to do the trick for Mr. Henry.

I heartily agree.
Given that 5500 dogs are euthanized each day in the US (see "Act of Dog") this article makes me cringe.

Every exhibitor at the event had the opportunity to donate some or all of the products in their booths to the local Humane Society. As an attendee, I saw almost every booth making huge donations at the end of the show, mostly of food and treats.

Additionally, several booths hosted local rescue groups along with their products and dozens of dogs found homes in those 3 days at the Expo.

Really wish the author of this article had put judgement aside for long enough to recognize all of the good that came out of this event.
Or better yet, an excise tax on pet products specifically earmearked for animal rescue costs.
Hoping there was a place to donate to a Humane Society or other animal charity.  Certainly if people don't mind spending money on the frills they can find it in their hearts to help the needy.
